title: Crypto Market Structure Bill: Behnam’s Crucial Push for Bankruptcy Protection
body: BitcoinWorld Crypto Market Structure Bill: Behnam’s Crucial Push for Bankruptcy Protection The world of cryptocurrency, while brimming with innovation and opportunity, has also been a wild west for many investors. Unforeseen collapses and murky legal frameworks have often left individuals in the lurch, with little recourse when things go wrong. This urgent need for clarity and security is precisely why U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) Chairman, Rostin Behnam, is championing a critical element for the forthcoming legislation: robust bankruptcy protection within the Crypto Market Structure Bill . But why is this specific safeguard so vital for your digital assets, and what does it mean for the future of crypto regulation ? Understanding the Proposed Crypto Market Structure Bill : Why is this Legislative Push So Vital? For years, the digital asset landscape has operated in a regulatory gray area. Is a cryptocurrency a commodity, a security, or something else entirely? This fundamental question has fueled jurisdictional battles among U.S. regulators, creating uncertainty for businesses and investors alike. The proposed Crypto Market Structure Bill aims to bring much-needed clarity by defining roles, responsibilities, and oversight for various digital assets and market participants. This bipartisan legislative effort seeks to establish a comprehensive framework that addresses several key areas: Clear Definitions: Distinguishing between digital commodities, digital securities, and other types of digital assets. Regulatory Oversight: Assigning clear jurisdiction to agencies like the CFTC and the SEC based on these definitions. Market Integrity: Implementing rules to prevent fraud, manipulation, and other illicit activities. Consumer Safeguards: Establishing protections for individuals engaging with crypto platforms and services. The goal is to foster innovation while simultaneously mitigating systemic risks and ensuring investor confidence. Without such a framework, the industry remains vulnerable to the kind of catastrophic failures we’ve witnessed in recent years. Why is Bankruptcy Protection the Core of Consumer Safety? The recent history of the crypto market is unfortunately littered with examples of platforms collapsing, leaving millions of users unable to access their funds. The most prominent case, FTX, vividly illustrated the devastating consequences of inadequate legal safeguards. When FTX filed for bankruptcy, customers discovered that their assets, which they believed were safely held, were commingled with corporate funds and used for speculative trading. This lack of segregation meant that customers were treated as unsecured creditors, at the back of a very long line, with little hope of recovering their full investments. This is precisely where bankruptcy protection comes into play. Chairman Behnam’s insistence on this element stems from a fundamental principle: when a crypto platform fails, users should have a clear and efficient path to reclaim their assets. In traditional finance, robust bankruptcy laws ensure that customer funds held by banks or brokerages are segregated and protected, allowing for their swift return even if the institution collapses. For digital assets, the challenge is complex due to the nature of blockchain technology and the various ways assets are held (e.g., custodial wallets vs. self-custody). A well-defined bankruptcy framework for crypto would aim to: Clarify Asset Ownership: Legally define whether customer digital assets held by a platform are truly customer property or part of the platform’s general estate. Ensure Segregation: Mandate that platforms keep customer funds separate from their operational capital. Provide a Recovery Path: Establish clear procedures for customers to reclaim their digital assets in the event of a platform’s insolvency. Reduce Delays and Costs: Streamline the bankruptcy process for crypto firms, minimizing the time and legal expenses involved in asset recovery. Without these explicit protections, investors remain exposed to significant risks, undermining trust and hindering the broader adoption of digital assets. The Pivotal Role of CFTC Behnam in Shaping Crypto Regulation Rostin Behnam has been a consistent and vocal advocate for clear and effective crypto regulation . As Chairman of the CFTC, an agency traditionally overseeing derivatives markets and commodities, Behnam has asserted the CFTC’s role in regulating certain digital assets, particularly those deemed commodities like Bitcoin and Ethereum. His approach emphasizes a ‘principles-based’ regulation that can adapt to the rapidly evolving crypto landscape, rather than a rigid, prescriptive one that might stifle innovation. Behnam’s focus on bankruptcy protection is a testament to his agency’s consumer-first approach. He has repeatedly highlighted the need for legislative action to grant regulators the necessary tools and authority to protect retail investors. His perspective is that while innovation is crucial, it must not come at the expense of fundamental investor safeguards. By advocating for bankruptcy clarity, Behnam aims to close a significant loophole that has repeatedly cost consumers dearly. The CFTC’s proactive stance, under Behnam’s leadership, signals a strong intent to bring the crypto derivatives market under a robust regulatory umbrella, ensuring fair trading practices and preventing market manipulation, all while prioritizing the safety of customer funds. Enhancing Consumer Protection in the Digital Asset Space: Are We Finally Moving Towards a Safer Crypto Landscape? While bankruptcy protection is paramount, it’s just one facet of comprehensive consumer protection in the digital asset space. A truly secure crypto environment requires a multi-pronged approach that addresses various risks. Beyond the immediate concern of insolvency, consumers need safeguards against: Fraud and Scams: Misleading projects, rug pulls, and phishing attacks. Market Manipulation: Pump-and-dump schemes and wash trading. Cybersecurity Risks: Hacking of exchanges and personal wallets. Lack of Transparency: Opaque business practices by platforms. Inadequate Disclosure: Insufficient information about risks associated with certain products or services. Effective crypto regulation should strive to create a level playing field where legitimate businesses can thrive, and bad actors are held accountable. This includes mandating robust cybersecurity measures, requiring clear risk disclosures, and empowering regulators to take swift enforcement action against illicit activities. The ultimate goal is to build trust, encouraging broader participation from both retail and institutional investors who currently shy away due to perceived risks. The push for the Crypto Market Structure Bill , with its emphasis on bankruptcy and broader consumer safeguards, represents a significant step towards maturing the digital asset industry. It acknowledges that for crypto to truly integrate into the global financial system, it must operate within a framework that mirrors the fundamental protections found in traditional markets. The Future of Crypto Regulation : Challenges and Opportunities The path to comprehensive crypto regulation is fraught with challenges. The rapid pace of technological innovation often outstrips the ability of lawmakers to draft relevant legislation. There’s also a delicate balance to strike between fostering innovation and implementing stringent controls that might stifle growth. Different jurisdictions also have varying approaches, leading to potential regulatory arbitrage. However, these challenges also present immense opportunities. A well-crafted regulatory framework, such as the one envisioned by the Crypto Market Structure Bill , can: Attract Institutional Investment: Provide the certainty and security that large financial institutions require. Boost Retail Confidence: Encourage more individuals to participate in the digital economy knowing their investments are protected. Foster Responsible Innovation: Guide developers and entrepreneurs towards building sustainable and compliant projects. Enhance Global Competitiveness: Position the U.S. as a leader in responsible digital asset development. Chairman Behnam’s advocacy for bankruptcy protection is a critical piece of this larger puzzle. It signals a pragmatic approach to regulation, addressing the most pressing pain points for consumers while laying the groundwork for a more stable and predictable crypto ecosystem. The ongoing dialogue between regulators, lawmakers, and industry participants is crucial to developing a framework that is both effective and future-proof. Conclusion: Securing the Digital Frontier The call from CFTC Chairman Rostin Behnam for explicit bankruptcy protection within the Crypto Market Structure Bill is not just a technicality; it’s a profound statement about the future of digital assets. It underscores a fundamental shift towards prioritizing investor safety and market integrity in an industry that has long operated with minimal oversight. By embedding clear rules for asset recovery in the event of platform failure, the U.S. aims to fortify its position as a hub for responsible crypto innovation, ensuring that the promise of decentralized finance can be realized without sacrificing the essential safeguards that protect everyday people. This crucial step promises to bring a new era of trust and stability to the volatile yet transformative world of cryptocurrencies, benefiting everyone from individual investors to the broader financial system. title: BitGo’s assets under custody jumped to $100B in H1 2025
body: The value of digital assets under BitGo Inc.’s custody has surged. BitGo’s vice president for its Asia-Pacific business, Abel Seow, said it had seen its assets under custody (AUC) rise from $60B to $100B in the first six months of the year. It represents a 66% increase , demonstrating the growing appetite among institutional and retail players to participate in the crypto-economy. Seow said that the rise was driven by “peak retail interest” in crypto, increasing asset adoption, and greater regulatory clarity in major jurisdictions. Crypto confidence is growing among investors, as is evident in the demand for secure and regulated custody services. One big driver of the increase in BitGo’s assets is “staking,” which involves crypto holders locking up their tokens to help validate blockchain transactions and, in exchange, earn passive income. Today, assets in BitGo Staking represent 50% of BitGo’s total holdings, where yield-based strategies are a core investment theme for modern digital asset holders. BitGo expands into global markets BitGo, which was established in 2013, initially offered secure wallets but has since developed into a one-stop shop crypto bank . In addition to custody, BitGo provides clients with the capabilities to trade, borrow, and lend digital assets. It has clients that include institutional investors and firms born on the blockchain. Over the past year, the company has been growing quickly internationally. BitGo Korea was released in September 2024 with Hana Financial Group and SK Telecom, two of South Korea’s largest financial and telecommunications companies. Seow said the joint venture is “progressing well” and has begun offering its services to high-net-worth clients and regional institutional participants. Also, in early 2025, BitGo officially seeded its Dubai operations, entering the region’s growing digital asset ecosystem. Crypto stronghold Dubai has established itself as a burgeoning hub in its own right on the backs of business-friendly regulation and investor appetite. BitGo’s growing reach reflects a larger trend in the industry; crypto firms no longer want to concentrate only on the US and Europe in traditional markets. Instead, they seek to go global to service local demand, particularly in areas where regulation is favorable and smartphone penetration rates are high. BitGo’s IPO strategy is part of a wider trend related to a change in the US approach under President Donald Trump’s administration, which has been particularly friendly to crypto since returning to office. title: Fact Check: Did The SEC Drop it’s Appeal Against Ripple?
body: The post Fact Check: Did The SEC Drop it’s Appeal Against Ripple? appeared first on Coinpedia Fintech News There’s been some confusion in the crypto world about whether the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) dropped its appeal against Ripple in March 2025. Let’s clear things up. In a video from March, called Crypto in a Minute , Ripple’s Chief Legal Officer, Stuart Alderoty, spoke about the case. He said, “I feel good,” as he reflected on the years of legal battles condensed into 60 seconds. Alderoty claimed that not only did the SEC drop its appeal against Ripple, but it also dropped all its enforcement actions against crypto companies in the U.S. He explained that the SEC finally admitted what Ripple and others had argued for years, that you can’t enforce laws without first clearly defining them. “We never had clear laws or regulations for crypto in this country,” Alderoty said. “Now, we’re going to clean up the mess, leave the courtrooms behind, and work with Congress to build smart rules that protect consumers and allow innovation to grow.” But Here’s What a Former SEC Lawyer Says However, former SEC attorney James Farrell s hared a different view on social media. He wrote, “The SEC still has not dropped its appeal. Both parties’ appeals are still alive (although stayed) today..” What’s Really Happening? To be clear, while the SEC’s appeal has been stayed (put on hold), it hasn’t been officially withdrawn. Both Ripple and the SEC still have active appeals in court. The case isn’t over yet, but there’s growing hope that clearer crypto rules will soon be created in the U.S. Ripple’s legal team is staying involved in those conversations, aiming to help shape fair regulations for the industry.
